Midterm was very difficult, attending the lectures and the seminars and studying from the book was not enough. Absolutely stupid system with bonus points - since the midterm was difficult, they are needed, but very difficult to gain, - seminars should be at least put in advance on website, so we can calculate it at home before the actual seminar, - there should be some voluntary homework, since for shy people is nearly impossible to solve a problem on blackboard in front of so many people (especially when we don't know the problem settings in advance). Magda Pečená should read the syllabuses of all financial courses on bachelor and then claim about some topic that it is easy and we know it from bachelor and then skip it.

My complaint is that instructors set-us up to fail the exams (24 average). Past years' exams were a better measurement of students' abilities. Also, instructors were extremely unhelpful. They never answered our emails when we had questions about assignments (i.e. credit application). Professors have too big of egos. By the way -> why would we be required to have 10 participation points when there are some 130 students, only 5-6 questions per class and 8-10 seminars? i.e. 5x8=40 points thats not enough for even half the students to got points -> which we needed since everyone failed the midterm.. I don't think studying harder is the issue, maybe instructors can't teach or they just give unfair exams.

English of all lecturers and seminarists. Solutions of seminars should be available online. The seminarists have very low presentation skills and virtually NO! interest in teaching. The materials for seminars should be provided in advance so the computations by students have some value (not only teacher telling the student what to write). The test should not be based on memorizing ridiculous formulas that can be easily looked up if needed. The test should be based on understanding not remembering bunch of letters.

I didn't like this course at all. I never understood lecturer's questions during the discussion. I never know what I was supposed to answer. I had difficulty in understanding lecturer's English. The required reading was very difficult for me because it was too philosophical, long and chaotic. I think that any other reading would be more useful. Writing memos was also difficult and I never recieved any feedback. Just the 'default' 75% and 'OK'. I don't know what I write wrong and how should I improve. Lecturer didn't pay attentions to the students. I believe that the content of the course is very useful but due to the manner of teaching/learning I am very disappoined.
sometimes I have no idea what the teacher wants from us - this may be quite discouraging

less emphasis on discussions about compulsory literature, more discussions about more in-depth issues would be appreciated, lecturer should introduce new information on additional issues during seminars, not only sum up compulsory literature

Discussions in class are not helpful in any way, as long as we can only repeat the outcomes presented in the reading. When it starts to be actually interesting, we are stopped and have to return to describing texts. Also the small-groups discussions are contraproductive, only consume time and we have to repeat it to the whole class later anyway. The lecturer's performance is not very good, he doeasn't explain much to us and his questions are often confusing - we don't know what he wants us to answer, where he is trying to lead us, so lot of people just gave up trying. The amount of required reading is sometimes incredibly big, regarding it is required for every seminar. More than hundered pages is impossible to process in such short time, plus we have also other courses and homeworks. Therefore, we are not able to read it properly anyway. Maybe it would be helpful to choose only important passages or chapters with key ideas. Organization through moodle was overall good, but I would recomended better distinction what is compulsory and when optional means truly not required.
